channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Who Is Fighting Whom in Syria
item.description: The Syrian civil war involves multiple countries with overlapping and at times conflicting agendas. Here is where some of the main foreign actors stand.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: The aftermath of a barrel bomb attack in a rebel-held area of Aleppo, Syria, earlier this month.

item.title: What the Oslo Accords Accomplished
item.description: When President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said he would not feel bound by the Oslo accords, he was repudiating the cornerstone of the Middle East peace process.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas, Palestinian Authority President, Says He’s No Longer Bound by Oslo Accords
item.description: Mr. Abbas accused Israel of having violated the accords, which formed the basis for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: 12 Sentenced in 2006 Bombings of Mumbai Commuter Trains
item.description: Five people were sentenced to death and seven to life in prison for their roles in the blasts, which killed at least 180 people and wounded 800 others.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: One of the 12 men convicted of planning several blasts on crowded commuter trains in 2006 in Mumbai, India, was escorted into court in Mumbai on Wednesday.

item.title: David Cameron Grapples With Issue of Slavery Reparations in Jamaica
item.description: Jamaica’s prime minister, Portia Simpson Miller, raised the issue with Britain’s prime minister, Mr. Cameron, during a visit to the Caribbean island.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Refugee Crisis in Europe Prompts Western Engagement in Syria
item.description: The rush of refugees into Europe has stirred new urgency among Western leaders to address the war in Syria and push harder for an end to it.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Migrants arriving on a northern shore of Lesbos, Greece, this week after crossing by rubber raft from Turkey.

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: U.S. Base Seen as Monument to Futility as Afghans Watch Kunduz Fall
item.description: An American base in Kunduz, Afghanistan, has become a refuge for hundreds of Afghan soldiers and civilians besieged by the Taliban forces that now control the city.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JAMES DAO
item.media:description: American soldiers on patrol in Kunduz, Afghanistan, in 2010.

item.title: Shaken by Taliban Victory in Kunduz, Afghans Flee Another Provincial Capital
item.description: The Afghan government was faced with not just retaking Kunduz, the northern city that fell to the Taliban on Monday, but also preventing a nearby city from falling as well.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: Afghan soldiers at the Kunduz airport prepared on Wednesday for a counteroffensive to try to retake the city from the Taliban.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn, Labour Party Leader, Says He’d Never Use Nuclear Weapons
item.description: Mr. Corbyn raised new questions from members of his own party about whether he would be a good choice to lead Britain’s military, one of the world’s most powerful.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Mob in India Kills Muslim Man Over Rumors of Cow Slaughter
item.description: Hindus consider the animals to be sacred, and murder charges have been filed against 10 people in connection with the death of the 52-year-old Muslim.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Relatives mourned Mohammad Ikhlaq at his home in Bisara, India, on Wednesday.

item.title: France Opens Criminal Investigation of Torture in Syria Under Assad
item.description: The investigation, based on thousands of photos of torture victims smuggled out of Syria by a police photographer, is hailed as an important, if symbolic, step.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The ‘Gatekeeper’ in Xi Jinping’s Inner Circle
item.description: Ding Xuexiang has emerged as the latest notable entrant into the Chinese president’s core group of advisers. Mr. Ding was serving as the head of the Shanghai party committee’s General Office in 2007 when Mr. Xi arrived there.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China at the White House state dinner held for him last week. Mr. Xi raised the profile of an adviser, Ding Xuexiang, when he was included in the guest list for the event.

item.title: Netanyahu Will Address U.N., but Focus May Be Healing Rift With U.S.
item.description: The Israeli prime minister, having failed in blocking the Iran nuclear deal, may use his speech before the United Nations General Assembly to make an overture to President Obama.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will speak before the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Launches Airstrikes in Syria, Adding a New Wrinkle
item.description: While Moscow’s stated purpose in Syria is to fight the Islamic State, the bombs hit an area not under the militants’ control.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Jinping Adviser Has Long Pushed for Powerful Leadership
item.description: An article by Wang Huning offers clues on how the party has been trying to reshape itself to lead the world’s second-largest economy without ceding authoritarian control.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: YUFAN HUANG
item.media:description: Wang Huning, third from the right, at an event with Boeing employees in Everett, Wash., during President Xi Jinping's visit to the United States. Mr. Wang is an adviser to Mr. Xi.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Clashes in Central African Republic
item.description: The country’s interim president rushed home from the United Nations General Assembly, as fears increased of a return of deadly sectarian violence.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: A wounded man on the floor of the General Hospital in Bangui, Central African Republic, on Saturday.

item.title: Series of Explosions in Southern China Kill at Least 7
item.description: The police identified a local man as the suspect in the blasts, which struck 13 sites and appeared to be caused by explosives left in parcels.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Letter From India: Why Narendra Modi Should Be Thanking Indian Politics
item.description: Politics may be the only system in India that offers a smart, impoverished young man a shot at success.
item.dc:creator: MANU JOSEPH
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at a Facebook event in Menlo Park, Calif., on Sunday. He became emotional while recounting his difficult childhood.

item.title: Toys ‘R’ Us Brings Temporary Foreign Workers to U.S. to Move Jobs Overseas
item.description: A federal program intended to bring in workers with special skills is being used by some American companies to hire and train other foreign workers.
item.dc:creator: JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Ben Solomon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Toys "R" Us store in Totowa, N.J. The retailer replaced 67 employees with workers in India. The Indian workers were trained by the American workers Toys "R" Us eventually laid off.

item.title: Beijing Journal: ‘China’s Mona Lisa’ Draws Long Lines and Heightened Fervor for Culture
item.description: Fanatical interest in a 12th-century painted scroll coincides with a concerted push by the Chinese government to encourage interest in traditional culture.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Beijing waiting to enter the Palace Museum in the Forbidden City to view a painted scroll considered so iconic that it is often called “China’s Mona Lisa.”
